dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: In the darkness, we hear a voice, a woman's voice.  Her n is Evey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Remember, remember, the fifth of November, the gunpowder treason and plot.  I know of now reason why the gunpowder treason should ever be forgot." Her voice has a strength that is metered by a calmness, a deep centered peace that we can feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those were almost the very first words he spoke to me and, in a way, that is where this story began, four hundred years ago, in a cellar beneath the Houses of Parliament. In the darkness, we find a lantern.  Guy Fawkes, a danger man who wears a goatee, is struggling with a wheelbarrow stacked with barrels of gunpowder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In 1605, Guy Fawkes attempted to blow up the Houses of Parliament. The wheelbarrow bumps over the heavy stone mortar of the cellar floor.  From the dark depths, we hear the sound of dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was caught in the cellars with enough gunpowder to level most of London. Guy sees lanterns coming from both sides.  He tries to ru the dogs reach him first.  He grabs for his sword as doze of pole axes pin him against the tunnel's stone wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wonder where we would be if he hadn't failed.  I wonder if it would have mattered. In the dim pre-dawn light, Guy is led to the gallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose the answer is in the rhyme.  More than the man, what we must remember is the plot itself. The coarse noose of rope is snugged up to Guy's throat. looks into the crowd until he finds a face, a woman's fac staring up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For in the plot we find more than just a man, we find the idea of that man, the spirit of that man, and that is what we must never forget. The lever is thrown and the woman looks down, a tear fall down her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This, then, is the story of that idea, of that spirit that began with an anarchist's plot four hundred years ago. Guy's body hangs in silhouette, lifeless against a red morning sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young Evey sits on her father's lap, combing her Barbie hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was born near the end of the millennium, the year 1997.  My father used to say that people were so afraid that the world was going to end that they were willing it to happen. Her father sits beside her mother on the living room couc watching the news.  From the look on their faces, the new bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember much of the century's turn.  I don't remember the market crash or the plague or any of the Trafalgar riots. The television flickers with images of heavily armed sold fighting in a shelled city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've read about them since but I don't recall how any of them impacted my life except for the fear.  They would hide it from me, like a secret between them. Little Evey sees her father staring at her mother.  They take hold of each other's hand, clasping them tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I could feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a new day.  People are gathered along the street as they were waiting for a parade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the chaos that seemed to swallow the beginning of the 21st century, there is one thing I do remember. Evey holds her father's hand.  Unable to see what is comi she can hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very clearly, I can remember that sound. We hear them, hundreds of marching soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I remember those boots, black leather that gleamed bright in the morning sun.  I had never seen such boots.  All moving in perfect unison. Little Evey hides in the forest of adults, clinging to he father's leg, staring as row after row of boots march by military precision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the midst of a political rally for the emerging new pa calling itself Norsefire, we find little Evey now on her father's shoulders. Dascombe, a young man, paces the podium, inciting the cro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The time has come, London, to return to a bygone age, an age of tradition, an age of values that have been disparaged and all but forgotten.  What this country needs is a leader!  A true leader to remind us of that age.  A righteous leader with the strength of his moral convictions to do what must be done.  I give you that man!  I give you our leader!  Adam Susan! Adam Susan rises and the crowd cheers.  Evey's father loo at her mother and again they clasp hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must have seemed so easy to them.  They offered such a simple deal; give up control and we will restore order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Evey is asleep in her bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first, the arrests were political.  Dissidents.  Radicals.  Liberals. A loud crash of splintering wood wakes her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When my parents were younger, they had been activists.  They had marched with Labor in the great train strike. The sound of heavy boots swarms through the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy? Her bedroom door bursts open and a heavily armed soldier scoops her up. She is carried through the dark house which is filled wit soldiers.  On the floor of the living room, she sees her parents being bound with plastic zip-ties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter!  Don't take my daughter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evey!  Evey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mommy!  Daddy! A heavy black hood is pulled over each of her parent's he as Evey is carried out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw them again.  Overnight, my life, my entire world was erased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nun with a switch in her crossed arms watches as Evey a several other little girls scrub the floor of a dormitory bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was done so quickly and violently, so completely, that it began to seem that it had never even existed. A tear rolls down Little Evey's cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gay man is dragged violently from his Piccadilly home.  Outside, he sees his lover being forced to the cobbleston

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The homosexuals were next.  What God had started with AIDS had to be finished by man.  It was God's work.  That's what we were told. He reaches for him as the clubs rise and fall, vicious an bloody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But once they were gone, there was someone else.  Someone different. In another neighborhood, we see the police arresting Pakistanis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone dangerous. In a different area, young black men are packed into a ca van so tightly they are unable to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were those who understood what was happening, who knew it was wrong but who kept silent. A young detective named Finch looks down as the van pulls away.  When he looks up, another man in a military unifor whose name is Almond is watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in the vacuum of that silence, order was imposed. Finch sticks his pipe in his mouth and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, we see the marching boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Order that was like those boots, order that required rigorous discipline.  Order that is exactly the same, where each single step falls with every step.  The order of the many shaped into one. We move through the columns of marching soldiers to a wal where a poster has been plastered up.  The poster reads, "Strength Through Purity, Purity Through Faith."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow in my heart, I knew it wouldn't last. As the sound of the marching fades, a shadow falls over t sign. After a moment, we hear the hiss of spray paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What they thought they had crushed, the spirit they believed trampled and ground beneath the marching of their boots, rose up, rose as if from a four hundred year old grave, rose to remind us all that day. The shadow sprays a "V" over the poster.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Close on a loudspeaker.  There is one on every major stre corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, London.  It's nine o'clock, the fourth of November in the year 2019 and this is the voice of Fate broadcasting on 275 and 285 of the medium wave. Beneath the loudspeaker is a surveillance system labeled, "For your protection." Bubble eyed lenses iris at the end of stalks that move, insect-like, racheting and clicking as they watch a littl girl pedal her bicycle.  The little girl glances nervousl over her shoulder up at the mechanical eyes watching her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People of London, be advised --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a radio on a small makeup table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- that Braxton and Streathon are quarantine zones as of today. Evey is now a young woman.  She slips into a dress that i little more than a nightgown.  She tries to adjust it, pulling it down at the hem, pulling it up at the thin shoulder straps, but it is like trying to hide behind a lamppost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is suggested that these area be avoided for reasons of health and safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another radio in a room that seems to be of another world

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good news following the productivity reports from Herefordshire indicating a possible end to meat rationing starting mid February. A man enters the room as he once entered the world.  His is lean and strong and though we do not see his face, the is a strength in his carriage, a power to his presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She packs tissue paper into the toes of a pair of high he that are too big for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police raided seventeen homes in the Birmingham area, uncovering what is believed to be a major terrorist ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move over a dressing bureau, past a wig and over a pai black leather gloves, moving until we find the mask; it i like something from the masquerade ball of another era. has an exaggerated goatee, harlequin cheeks and a smile, forever fixed, at once be-guiling and be-deviling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty eight people, eight of them women, are currently in detention awaiting trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evey coats her lips with a lascivious red.  She stares in the mirror, her makeup like a mask over her own face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that is the face of London tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man, now fully dressed in cloak, hat, and mask gazes the mirror. This is V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is the voice of Fate signing off and bidding you a pleasant evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on Evey's high heels, stumbling and awkward as she walks down a dark cobblestoned street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on V's boots walking in the opposite direction so t it seems they are walking towards each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what brought us together that night.  I had never been to that part of Westminster but ever since I've known him, I've stopped believing in coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evey looks up and sees a man standing mostly in shadow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?  Uh... excuse me, Mister? The man turns around.  It is not V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like... uh, would you like to sleep with me? He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, for money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is the clumsiest bit of propositioning I've ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this your first time, darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, no, I mean for money.  But I know what you want and I'll do it. She presses her body to his, using her little girl eyes a her woman's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything you want, mister.  Please, I need the money.  I know I'm young but I promise I know what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You don't know what you're doing. He pulls out his wallet and shows her a badge.  The sight it knocks the breath out of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, you're a Fingerman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give the little lady a prize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got something to give her. Evey turns and there are more Fingermen behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prostitution is a class H offense.  Know what that means?  It means that we get to exercise our own judicial discretion --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you get to swallow it. The Fingermen laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god, please.  It's my first time.  Please don't hurt me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh, fellas, look at those big innocent eyes.  What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spare the rod, spoil the child. Fingerman 2 laughs hard as he drops his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no! He shoves her face first against a brick wall, lifting he dress to expose her bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard the man, sweetie.  This rod's for your own good. Suddenly, they are no longer alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The multiplying villainies of nature do swarm upon him."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "And fortune, on his damned quarrel, smiling, showed like a rebel's whore."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're police officers, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're with the Finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So bugger off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Disdaining fortune with his brandished steel, which smoked with bloody execution." In the clenched fist of black leather, we see a flash of steel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a knife! V attacks and at once we know this is no normal human bei A single blow sends the largest of the Fingermen flying backwards. But more than his strength, it is his speed. A gun is cocked but before the hammer falls, a knife is buried in the Fingerman's chest and -- Before the body falls, the knife is gone. It takes a handful of seconds and three bodies lay on the ground.  V turns to the last Fingerman who is struggling pull his pants up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!  Don't hurt me! V steps forward and he screams, bolting while holding his pants up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who -- Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?  I imagine all manner of names shall be heaped upon my humble visage but, for now, let us simply say I am the villain. He throws wide his cloak and bows deeply to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you would be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. They hear sirens rushing towards them.  In a blink, he sc her up and dashes into the shadows of a narrow alleyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police cars and several ambulances swarm over the area wi the dead Fingermen. V watches them from above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you do that?  Why did you... help me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why indeed? He takes out an old antique pocket watch.  It is almost midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, music.  My music.  You see.  Evey, I am a performer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that why you're wearing a mask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all wear masks.  Life creates them and forces us to find the one that fits.  Do you know what day it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... November fourth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for long. He looks out where, rising above the rooftops, he can see Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Remember, remember, the fifth of November, the gunpowder treason and plot.  I know of no reason why the gunpowder treason should ever be forgot." The second hand sweeps into the final minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Evey, what good is an actor that plays his part to an empty theatre?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor do I.  That's why you are here.  I need you, Evey.  I need someone to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To your music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Yes, to my music. From his sleeve, he pulls a conductor's wand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you hear it?  It's already begun. He begins to lightly tap the wand in the air and, very faintly, we hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't hear anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first, you have to listen very carefully... He continues to conduct and we begin to hear the music, violins and horns that seem almost like a whisper or a wi that steadily swells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, yes.  There it is.  Beautiful, is it not? He turns to the parapet, his gestures growing grander as music rises and we recognize Tchaikovsky's 1812 overture. The music mounts a climax and V points the wand at Big Be cymbals crash -- Big Ben explodes with such force the world seems to shake while -- V, smiling, always smiling, points again with another crescendo and -- The statue of justice is blown to smithereens. V nods in appreciation while mustering the music towards finale as fireworks begin lighting up the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my... Everywhere across the city, people stand transfixed by th dazzling shimmer of the fireworks until -- A strobing final blitz leaves a single, starry image floa in the smoke filled sky. It is the letter V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. From every direction, the city screams with the panicked sound of sirens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A massive modern building that is the seat of the new government. A long, black car pulls up to the entrance.  Adam Susan g out, wearing a long black trenchcoat over his pajamas.  H the Leader and he looks older, heavier, and meaner. He hurries past the heavily armed guards, barely acknowledging the snap and cock of their Nazi-like salute

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Leader enters his main chambers and we see the Fate computer system. It is a cerebral cortex for a vast intelligence network.  Information can almost be felt coursing through its hard drives. The Leader sits, at once regaining a measure of composure He takes a deep calming breath and accesses the system. Dozens of monitors fill with images from all across the c most of them are of the damage caused by V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I will hear your reports now.  Mr. Heyer, speak for the Eye. Conrad Heyer appears on one of the screens.  He is at his desk inside the command center for the Eye, the governmen organization responsible for the visual surveillance syst

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have less than two minutes of usable footage, Leader.  It took the suspect less than a minute to dispatch the Finger's vice patrol. On an insert screen, we see grainy footage of V rescuing from one of the pole-mounted cameras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you can see, the suspect's reflex speed is extraordinary.  As is his strength. As the last body falls, V seems to pause and looks back o his shoulder straight into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freeze it! The Leader stares at the smiling face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid the mask makes retinal identification impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Etheridge, report for the Ear! Bunny Etheridge appears on another screen.  Behind him, h spooling reels of audiotape wind constantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were able to triangulate the origin of the fireworks.  We also are currently monitoring a lot of phone surveillance indicating a high percentage of conversation concerned with the explosions.  All suspect or significant transcripts are being forwarded to Mr. Almond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good.  Mr. Finch, speak for the Nose. Finch, no longer the same young man, stands at the site o the fireworks launch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks to Etheridge, we found the launch for the fireworks.  These appear to be individually weighted flares and we have found traces of the same chemicals at both of the detonation sites which leads us to conclude that, despite a level of sophistication, these devices are all home-made with over the counter chemicals, making them impossible to trace.  Whoever he is, Leader, he's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for that professional annotation. An intercom opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leader, Mr. Almond has arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good.  Gentlemen, keep me informed of any further developments.  England prevails. They answer in unison as Almond enters the office.  His f is harder but he has the same violent gleam in his eye. The Leader turns in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Almond, do you know what this is behind me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... the Fate computer system, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No sir.  It's more than that.  This, this computer is a symbol, Mr. Almond.  A symbol of the highest attainable goal of mankind.  Do you know what that goal is, Mr. Almond? Almond does not.  The Leader leaps from his chair while pounding the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Control, Mr. Almond!  Control!  The world around us is a changing, directionless, amoral morass and it is up to man and man alone to set things right! He moves around the desk at Almond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without control, man is nothing more than any other stinking, sweating, brute animal.  Control, Mr. Almond.  The control that we have painstakingly built up over the last ten years.  Now, do you understand what happened last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We... lost control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Almond.  Last night someone did the unthinkable.  Someone hurt us.  It is imperative that we act swiftly and precisely.  I want that man found, Mr. Almond.  I want his head or, by god, I'll have yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evey is wearing a blindfold and V leads her by her fingertips, guiding her almost as if they were dancing... His fingers slip free of her and she reaches out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.  I've lost you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you haven't. He is behind her and he removes the blindfold, revealing house to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... It is a labyrinth of interconnecting underground tunnels rooms. The gallery is the main room as it is filled with an amaz collection of human culture.  There is art that spans fro the renaissance to the painted covers of Eerie comics, literature that ranges from Shakespeare to Spillane, philosophy from Plato to Bukowski, and a vast collection nonfiction. There are movie posters everywhere and an entire wall is lined with videocassettes. A jukebox stands in front of an enormous vinyl and CD collection of music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jukebox?  Where did you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saved it.  Like everything here. She punches a button and Billie Holiday begins to sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's beautiful.  I've never heard anything like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.  You grew up in their world.  Art is created by individuals and there are no individuals in a world where you are told what to think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place is amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome to stay. She stops suddenly and looks at him.  The offer is terrib exciting but it is so unlike anything she has ever done t it's almost impossible to imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here... with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  If you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I don't even know your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a name.  But you can call me V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V?  V... I like that. And she returns his smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only operating broadcast tower in London; home of the Mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis Prothero leans forward and lets his voice pour like syrup over the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, London.  This is the voice of Fate -- Damn. He stops and coughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning -- ack.  Good morning Lond-- Goddammit!  Where is my bloody tea?! In the control booth, Roger Dascombe, his hair thinner no rubs his temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would someone get his lordship his bloody tea? He clicks on the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis, they want this report on the first hour --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I know.  Damned inconvenient this entire affair.  Fine.  Let's try again. He clears his voice and the red "record" light turns on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, London.  It is 6 am, the fifth of November 2019 and this is the voice of Fate.  The new day brings good news and bright prospects from overseas, where negotiations with New China are moving in a positive direction.  Last night's scheduled demolition of two deteriorating landmarks went off without a hitch. Dascombe is unable to stop himself from smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spokesman for the Interior ministry said both structures were severely damaged and judged to be a danger to the unsuspecting public.  Plans for new landmarks are well underway. Prothero sits back, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe this crap, Dascombe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not our job to believe it, Lewis.  Our job is to tell the people --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Exactly what they tell us."  I Know but do you think that people will believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will if it's you that's telling it to them.  Now let's try it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V is alone, listening to the first morning broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... plans for new landmarks are already well underway. He clicks off the radio.  Walking down a hall, he stops a peers into Evey's new bedroom. She is fast asleep, looking remarkably at peace.  Quietly shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are hurrying to board a departing train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prothero is staring out his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Remember, remember, the fifth of November..." He talks to his bodyguards almost as if talking to himsel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you suppose that's why he did it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, who did what, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy Fawkes.  He tried to blow up Parliament. The guards look at each other, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't they teach history in school anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, we're both straight military, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, yes, sir.  I was fighting in Ireland by the time I was sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course.  My mistake. He turns back to his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train rumbles along, heading for a tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prothero watches the countryside rolling past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love trains.  I remember riding the underground with my father.  Shame they shut them all down. Bodyguard 1 looks out the opposite window just as the tra enters the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a flashing instant, we see V in silhouette, cloak swirling around him like dark wings as he jumps from the bridge onto the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prothero and Bodyguard 2 stare at Bodyguard 1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I saw a man jumping onto the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train's doing almost seventy.  It would break his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, I... It must have been rags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep in the tunnel, a dark figure glides across the rooft

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conductor hears something on the roof.  He peers up j as V swings down, smashing feet first into the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brakes suddenly lock, throwing Bodyguard 2 into Proth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get off of me! A moment later, the lights are cut off and the entire tra is plunged into complete darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock the car doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a lighter... somewhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't find the lock -- wait.  Hey wha-- There is a muffled shriek followed by a sharp snap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening -- There is another sound, like the leather slap of a boxer pounding a heavy bag, followed by the sound of the heavy collapsing onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found it! He flicks on the lighter and, in the dim light of its fla he sees the smiling face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god. V sits casually, arms folded, across from Prothero.  The bodyguards lay dead on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?  What do you want?  Money?  Is that it? V just smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, wait.  You're, you're the one that blew the Bailey. V nods and Prothero's eyes go wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making a mistake.  I'm nobody -- On the floor, he sees the bodyguard's gun.  He kills the lighter and dives for it. In the darkness, we hear the struggle.  It ends quickly.  When the lighter flicks back on, V is holding it and the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come to offer you a choice.  Commander Prothero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What -- What did you call me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander Prothero. Prothero's heart begins to pound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was your title at Larkhill.  You remember Larkhill, don't you, Commander?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign reads, "Larkhill Resettlement Camp."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where they sent the undesirables. A caged truck packed with minorities rolls into the gates which are topped with spools of razor wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prothero is sweating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I can help your memory.  Let's see.  Larkhill opened in the summer of 2009.  You were appointed it commander.  You wore a uniform in those days.  You looked very good in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prothero admires his uniform in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were a man of many responsibilities.  You made sure Larkhill made all its quotas, especially the oven quotas even though they required an excessive amount of maintenance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a detail of black and Indian men, shoveling mounds black ash from a series of furnace like ovens. As the shovels lift, we see blackened bones and burnt sku

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prothero saunters through the lines of camp prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there was one task you took to with exceptional relish.  Remember the medical block, Commander?  I believe you called it the funny farm.  You were the one that selected the prisoners.  You hand picked each one. Prothero steps in front of a woman who remains beautiful despite the suffering she has endured.  Prothero smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her. As the guards grab her, we become aware of a man that is staring at Prothero.  He is one of the prisoners but we d not see his face. Prothero notices the man.  He doesn't like the way the ma staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prothero is terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You!  You're him, aren't you? V nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god!  What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave us a choice, remember, Commander?  You said we could cooperate with the doctors or... V cocks the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold out your hand. Trembling, Prothero sticks out his hand.  V lets the ligh die for a moment. When he flicks it back on, Prothero is holding a long, me syringe filled with a murky liquid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, no!  Please I was just doing what I was told!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you were.  Now I'm telling you to make a choice.  Either you stick that syringe into your neck or -- He presses the gun barrel to Prothero's forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can kill you right now. Prothero begins to blubber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crying doesn't help, Commander.  I remember there was a woman who had been screaming for two days.  You winked at the doctor and laughed, "All in the name of science."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, don't make me do this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a difficult choice, isn't it?  Certain death versus something that might be... worse.  But you never know.  There is still a chance.  You could survive.  Look at me.  Now, time's up, Commander.  Choose. Anger galvanizes his fear and steadily Prothero lifts the needle towards his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you in hell. He jams the needle in and sinks the plunger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I'm quite sure you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Train workers with flashlights hurry through the cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This door's locked! He slams a shoulder against it and the door gives in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy Christ! Flashlights sweep over the dead bodyguards.  The train ma hears a strange gurgling rasp and he turns, finding Proth in his light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened here? Prothero is foaming at the mouth while a thick mucus bubb from his nose.  His breath comes in tiny rasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good lord!  I need a medic here. Prothero becomes more animate, trying to tell the man something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fi... Fi... Fi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's trying to say something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five?  Where's the goddamn medic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room five. Suddenly, his body convulses and blood pours out his ears His body slumps over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he needs a priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station is swarming with police.  A stretcher wheels body in a black plastic bag out from Prothero's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finch puffs on his pipe, staring at something spray paint on the wall of the train car: a "V" with a circle around

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you make of this, Mr. Finch? Dominic, Finch's younger assistant, is holding a flower i his rubber gloved hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm.  It's a rose.  A violet carson, I believe.  Strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strange?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think they still existed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Finch!  Sir! Finch turns as a soldier with a radio steps into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, they want you at headquarters, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  I'm to transport you immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send the rose to the lab.  Also, scrape a sample of this paint and have it analyzed as well.  I'll be back as soon as I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Finch steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Mr. Finch.  I sent for you because what I have to say cannot be said over a phone or a radio.  What I have to say cannot leave these four walls.  Do I make myself clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe in a few things, Mr. Finch.  I believe in god.  I believe in the destiny of the Nordic race.  And I believe in fascism.  The romans invented fascism.  They had a symbol for it; a bundle of twigs bound together.  One twig could be broken but a bundle would prevail.  That is the heart and soul of fascism.  Strength in unity.  I tell you these things knowing full well that they make you uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have in fact expressed your discomfort in several arrest reports, arrests that were, in your opinion, "unnecessary."  The fact that you are here, that you are not rotting in a prison cell, is a mark of my respect and admiration for you, for your craft, and for what you have done for this country. Finch looks at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is also because I know you, Finch.  I know what you are.  You're a man like me.  A man who understands when they are given a job what must be done.  I understand you, Finch, and that is why I can trust you. He moves in close to Finch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This terrorist knows us, Finch.  These attacks are perfectly calculated and they are divisive.  He knows what he's doing, Finch.  He knows us all too well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think he's an insider?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I think is that this man must be stopped.  Stopped at all costs and no one, I repeat, no one is to be placed above suspicion.  Do I make myself clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: England prevails, Mr. Finch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: England prevails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evey, alone in the Shadow Gallery, stares up at the inscription above the crooked staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V, v, v, v, v.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear your summons, my lady.  And obey. She jumps, V suddenly appearing behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, V, you scared me. She turns back to the carving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was reading the inscription.  What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Latin quotation.  A motto.  "Vi veri veniversum vivus vici."  "By the power of truth, I, while living, have conquered the universe." She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I suppose you have.  This place is the only universe I have right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that bother you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I'm so grateful to you -- I just feel I should help you, you know, the way you're helping me.  I mean, that's the deal, isn't it? V drifts over to the big old Wurlitzer, fingers scanning song list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No deals, Evey.  Not unless you want them. She looks up at the inscription as an old blues song begi to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I do.  Part of me wants to stay here forever and never have to face what's going on outside.  But that's not right.  Is it?  That's not taking responsibility.  Not conquering my universe. She turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to help you, V.  I want to do something.  Can we make a deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I think we can make a deal if you like.  I think I know a way you could help me very soon indeed. Evey smiles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  That's that, then. The blues song curls in the air around them like a heavy incense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V, you said that Latin thing was a quote.  Who said it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody you'd have heard of.  A German gentleman named Dr. John Faust. He spins her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made a deal too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The church doors have opened with the flow of parishioner the final mass of the day has ended. The tide slowly pours out onto the sidewalk, separating around the clumps of people that conglomerate to network gossip. Church bells toll in the orange dusk above them. Helen Heyer, a woman whose spite and guile are hidden beh her looks and clothes she drapes them with, charges into gossipers, her trophy husband in tow, a timid looking man that we recognize as Conrad Heyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Rosemary.  Derek, how -- Helen's head snaps over at the mention of the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derek! She pushes past Conrad, giving Derek Almond an exuberant on both cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, how are you?  Hello, Rosemary. Always behind her husband, Rosemary Almond smiles nervous as she straightens her drab church dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so good to see you.  Since this bloody terrorist business, the old man has me literally chained to the office. Helen pouts at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you poor dear. Derek taps the bottom of his cigarette box, drawing one w his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It comes with the job.  How are things in the Eye, Conrad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we've been working some bugs out of the new Mark IX fiber optic network, actually --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Conrad, don't be such a bloody bore.  Do tell us about the terrorist, Derek.  Is it true he blew up Big Ben and the old Bailey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so.  We're dealing with a pathological psychotic in the most extreme case.  We'll catch him though.  I promise. Helen rubs her white sable against her body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it sounds dreadfully exciting.  Aren't you glad you've got such a ruthless, implacable brute for a husband, Rosemary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, you're lucky.  You could be struck with a professional peeping tom like Conrad.  England's highest paid voyeur, aren't you darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen, I think we'd better --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, of course.  We have to get back so the little pervert can watch what the neighbors do after Sunday lunch.  He's so exciting. Derek laughs as they climb into their car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ciao!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Helen.  Conrad. Rosemary waves as it pulls off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a bit hard on him, isn't she? Derek sneers at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until you're half the woman of Helen's sophistication, I'd keep your little mouth shut. He throws the cigarette at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, just look at the way you dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From above, a hand sweeps aside the red plush curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, there they go.  My happy and contented flock.  Spiritually refreshed and ready to face the world again. Bishop Anthony Lilliman is a slender man of pious eleganc with a warm, beautiful smile. He turns from the window to his valet, Dennis, as Derek a Rosemary get in their car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you enjoy the sermon today, Dennis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very inspiring, your grace.  Though the segue of the forces of Satan among us did strike me as a bit of a curious digression. He whisks a lint brush over the Bishop's robes before put them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm, yes.  A trifle purple, I thought.  Still, Fate wanted it included and who are we to question the will of the almighty, miserable sinners that we are? A gentle smile spreads across his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And speaking of sin, I wonder which of the seven deadlies the good lord will see fit to tempt me with today. Dennis finishes with the Bishop's robes and sweeps the cl door shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps pride, your grace. Lilliman chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking of something a little less ethereal.  Has the young lady arrived?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agency informed me she'll be here directly.  However, there was a mixup.  It's not one of the usual girls.  She's a little older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear.  Oh dear.  Not too old, I trust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They promise me she's no more than fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen, hmm. The Bishop rubs his cheek, ponderously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah well, if Job could bear his disappointments, I suppose I must have the good grace to bear mine.  Show her in when she arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, your grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of headlights melt through the heavy night's fog a taxicab pulls into the circle drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis peers into the Bishop's living quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young lady, your grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my! Standing next to Dennis is Evey, wearing a frilly pink su dress, pigtails and bows and white ruffled socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to think I doubted your loveliness for even an instant.  Mea culpa, my child, mea culpa.  You are a vision.  An angel. Evey smiles awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shadow begins moving across the manicured grounds borne the thick mist like a dark phantom.  V glides toward the rectory, cloak undulating against the dark, wet wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is extravagantly furnished, somewhere between posh and pimp.  The Bishop is sitting very close to Evey on his pl water bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, "hate the sin, love the sinner."  I always say.  Take your dress off, please. Evey stammers, backing up along the bedside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen -- I was kind of hoping -- He paws at her, groping hands pushing the front of her dr down as she backs up against the nightstand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guards look out into the night, fear suddenly grippin their faces. V emerges demonically through the parting veils of fog, t white smiling mask bobbing eerily up and down as he rushe them. A cigarette drops from the first guard's mouth, red ember exploding when it hits the wet cement. Close as the two guards claw for their arms and the white flash of V's knives -- That slice like talons. The two men crumple to the ground, clutching their gaping gurgling wounds.  A whisper.  V sprints into the courtyar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evey grabs a metal table lamp and swings it down on the Bishop's head.  There is a shuddering clank and he collap to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You -- You filthy whore! His blood speckles the white bearskin throw rug as the Bi slowly rises after the retreating Evey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll kill you, you fucking sow. He charges after her but freezes dead in his tracks as V swings around the corner in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?  Who --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please allow me to introduce myself... V bows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a man of wealth and taste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dennis? Instantly, the point of one of V's knives is against the Bishop's throat.  V presses a finger to his frozen smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh.  It isn't polite to disturb the dead on their journey. Evey watches from around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A courtesy I'll most respectfully extend to his grace.

dialogues.speaker: V
dialogues.text: Lilliman swallows audibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vi veri veniversum vivus vici, Evey. Evey looks down at the knives on his belt, dripping blood

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. She begins backing to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't kill him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death has followed his grace the whole of his career.  Is it any coincidence it has finally followed him here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god, V.  I can't -- I can't -- V turns back to Lilliman as Evey runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us pray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evey sprints past the dead guards at the man gate and int the fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cramped control room that looks like something between radio and television switching room, though it does not broadcast.  It receives. Two operators sit at the main substation as the sounds of lovemaking come over the speakers.  The moans are stifled low, however, as if they were afraid someone was listenin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody hell.  Doesn't anybody fuck with feeling anymore? Operator 2 does not look at him, scrolling through an intricate city map on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's Sunday.  Children's hour over at the Abbey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see what that filthy old pervert is up to. Operator 1 punches in some coordinates and the sound over speakers changes to a garbled fart of noise.  Two voices drown beneath a cacophony of classical music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the -- He tries to dial out the background and suddenly the voic rise clearly above the din.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And I saw a black shape against the flames.  Oh god.  It's you.  The man from room five.  You've come --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To collect what's mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg you!  I don't want to die!  Please have mercy! The two men look at each other, Operator 1 lunging for a phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me the Finger.  This is an emergency!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a stain of white vomit and blood on the thick pi of a Persian rug.  It is encircled in police chalk. Pull back to reveal the chalk outline where the body of Bishop Lilliman was found.  The circled bloodstain floats above the head like the last word balloon of a crude comi strip character. The Bishop's quarters is slowly being picked over by a forensic team from the Nose.  A photographer's flash burs against a painted "V" on the wall near the body outline. At the window, Finch chews on his pipe, staring at a plas evidence bag that contains a single violet carson rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No prints yet, sir.  Just like Prothero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want those tapes from the Ear in my office tonight, Dominic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  They're on top of it. Finch turns to a muscular man named Creedy, second in com at the Finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any word from your superior, Mr. Creedy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Almond doesn't seem to be answering his page, sir.  I'm sure he's in the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grunting like an animal, Derek's face is frozen, locked i the rigor of a violent orgasm.  After a moment, he collap beside Helen onto the sweat soaked sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go, baby.  Now my baby boy can think so much clearer.  Can't he? She grabs her cigarette case and her lighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been thinking, haven't you? She straddles his chest then lights two cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you have.  Ever since this terrorist appeared. He smiles as she puts one of the cigarettes in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh jesus, that smile.  That smile turns me on like nothing else. She whispers in his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me.  Tell me what's going on in that ruthless sadistic brain of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is so worried about the terrorist.  Especially Susan.  You know why?  Because nobody knows what he's going to do. He exhales through his grinding teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I were him, I know what I'd do. He whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd blow that fat bastard to kingdom come. Helen bolts up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I? He smiles, blowing more smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an old train line under the New Government Building.  It collapsed when they poured the foundation.  You could haul in enough TNT to launch our Leader's ass all the way to the moon. Helen's eyes gleam as he laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're serious, aren't you? He eyes her sucking on the cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to be careful, Helen.  Your mouth is going to get you into trouble one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the same trouble you love putting in my mouth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know who might be listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Derek.  You love your country and you love your party, just like you love your wife. He glares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derek.  I'm sorry.  I know I can be a bitch.  But that's why you're here, isn't it? He smiles again and she presses her body to his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it, isn't it, Derek?  What we've been waiting for.  At last, you'll be rid of Susan.  I'll be rid of Conrad.  And we'll be free.  Free, won't we? His eyes close as he grinds his hips into hers and we ris drifting up to the ceiling light fixture -- Where we see a tiny hidden microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finch sits at his desk, staring into the silence of his notepad.  He has doodled a little "V" with a circle aroun it. He looks up as Dominic enters, holding up a portable cass player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry it took so long.  The boys had a devil of a time trying to filter out the background noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Background noise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The perpetrator apparently turned on the Bishop's stereo.  Subsequently, a great deal of the tape is useless. He hands the player to Finch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What music did he play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beethoven.  The fifth, I believe. Finch smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Da, da, da, dum.  That's code.  Morse code.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the letter "V". Finch punches "play". Over the small speaker, we sear Evey protesting to V, the run.  He stops it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything on the girl yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  The agency said somebody claiming to be Lilliman's valet canceled his Sunday appointment. Finch starts it again and this time the tape is very fuzz

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23rd Psalm. We recognize some of the words though muted and crackly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes on like that for a while.  Fairly incoherent except we could make out a few words in this part.  Transubstantiation. Finch nods, understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That miracle business when the wafer transform into the body of Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made him eat a host.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, listen to this part. The tape becomes somewhat clearer as the music rests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And at the moment this enters your mouth it becomes the flesh of the savior?  Yes... please... And whatever it is made of now it will become the body of Christ?  Yes... yes... They eye each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to swallow it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a couple of funny human noises...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then just Beethoven's fifth. He shuts off the tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have got the initial path report back.  The host was full of cyanide. Finch picks up the bag with the violet carson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do you know what? He rises, sliding into his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it reached his abdomen, it was still cyanide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on the heavy stitching of a "Y" incision sewn into chest of a corpse.  It is one of the Bishop's guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a motive? Finch is standing next to the cadaver gurney with the coroner, Delia Surridge.  She is a serious woman, hair wo tight behind her head in a severe bun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, was anything taken? She fills the dead man's head with cotton and replaces th top of his skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just lives. Pulling at the man's scalp, she stretches it over the replaced skull piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's too early for your profile but do you have any initial impressions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... She points at a jagged puncture wound at the base of the man's sternum with a ball point pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's incredibly powerful.  This man's sternum was split like dry wood from the base all the way up to the manubrium. Finch peers into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's resourceful.  On that table behind you is a breakdown of all the chemicals found in Prothero's blood stream. Finch hefts the pile of computer paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were hundreds of different chemicals in him.  From trinitrotoluene to estrogen to motor oil. He flips through the document, biting into the wooden end his pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps Fate will make something more of all this.  I certainly can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Leader finally authorized an uplink for you?  He must be getting nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite.  Government directed terrorism never sews healthy ideas into the public.  Oh, that reminds me. Finch pulls the evidence bag from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tell us anything about this? Delia's eyes lock onto the violet carson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found one in the carriage with Prothero and this one in the Bishop's quarters.  A violet carson. He hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard that strain had died off.  Thought a botanist might shed some light on it.  Delia? Delia, riveted to the rose, suddenly looks up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magic.  I'll drop by tomorrow then. He turns, leaving her with the rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V relaxes with a book in an overstuffed reading chair, a violet carson rose resting on a table next to him.  He be to read a passage aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "There is more behind and inside of V than any of us had suspected.  Not who, but what: what is she?" He places the book down.  Thomas Pynchon's "V". V rises, lifting the rose and moving into the darkness of Shadow Gallery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small figure moves down the dark wet street, the cobblestones glistening like black scales. The huddled figure arcs across the street in the shadows, avoiding the pools of streetlight.  It is Evey, a frighte look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman in combat boots, fishnets, and a tight fitting soldier's uniform is in the middle of a cheeky number on stage in this smoky burlesque bar.  It is a popular place with locals and Fingermen. Peter Creedy squeezes through the crowd, angling for the of the bar where a number of loud Fingermen are drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all this, then, Harper?  I get a radio that a man's down and in need of assistance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't gone down yet but I sure do need some assistance. Creedy leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you flat broke already? They break up in laughter, led by Creedy who sits next to Harper, pouring himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you sneak away, Creedy?  Almond off buggering that blonde chippy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one with the tits? They all begin to hoot and whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I wouldn't give for a piece of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She could serve a tray of drinks on those thingies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you get your chance with her sooner than later, Creedy, with the way Almond's crackin' up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody bugger's losing his marbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrorist or no, if that bastard gives me another double shift, I'll stomp his fucking head. Creedy raises his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.  This nonsense has put a serious strain on my drinking.  I think I was actually sober today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drink to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to get a real man of the people in that director's position.  Like Creedy here. Everyone cheers in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's good to know when the shit hits the fan who your real friends are. They salute and drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derek Almond sits hunched under a desk lamp, pumping the cylinders of his revolver with a wire brush. Rosemary shuffles up to him, her frumpy gown gathered aro her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derek -- He blows down one of the cylinders, not looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hear it, Rosemary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derek, please!  We can't carry on like this. Derek stares at the gun, rage building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't talk to me.  You don't eat with me.  You don't have sex -- Derek leaps up, slugging her. Rosemary clatters to the ground in tears.  Derek glowerin over her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to take any crap from you!  I have that fat bastard riding me all day.  I don't want to listen to you, so shut your fat gob! He leans into her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And me not wanting to fuck you is obvious.  Take a look at yourself. He sits back in front of the gun, wiping it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of my sight.  I'm cleaning my gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Surridge sits somberly in the dark, street light filtering in from the open curtains. Her eyes fixed on the violet carson as she slowly turns i over in her hands, fingers tracing the soft petals. After a moment, she stands, letting it fall from her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finch turns as Dominic bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A connection? Dominic waves a printout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larkhill Resettlement Camp.  Prothero's and Lilliman's employment records show they both help positions there at similar times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about codename V?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of Larkhill's records were destroyed for security reasons but I did uncover an old standard procedures and operations manual. Dominic smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In special case studies, medical research groups used roman numerals to identify test inmates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five is the letter V.  Brilliant, Dominic. Finch slides in front of his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we need is Larkhill's employment records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The covers pulled protectively up around her, Delia rests a light, uneasy sleep. Suddenly, an eye pops open as she awakens, catching a familiar scent.  She slowly sits up and inhales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roses. She closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's you, isn't it?  You've come to kill me. From the shadows, V answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Tears begin to streak her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh thank god.  Thank god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dominic hangs over Finch's shoulder as Larkhill's employm record comes up. Finch's mouth falls open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god. Row after row of names scroll by at the end of each bio a the words: deceased, file closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh bloody hell. The data banks unfurl like a mass grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's killed them all?  It's not possible. Finch stops, staring at the one name whose file is not closed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. Dr. Delia Surridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V floats on the edge of the room's shadows, a dark angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you afraid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.  I thought I would be, but I'm not.  I'm -- She looks at the hovering, smiling mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relieved. She starts to cry again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god, all these years.  All this waiting.  And somehow I always knew you'd come back. Delia thinks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I saw you that night -- the night you escaped, you were standing against the flames and you looked straight at me. The mask almost nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew then that one day you'd come looking for me, that you'd find me. Her voice drops to an almost confessional whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What -- what happened at Larkhill.  What we did -- What I did.  That terrible knowledge, it's been with me so long.  That I could do things like that. Delia rubs the salty tears from her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For years, I blamed it on the government, on the authority I could never stand up to.  But living so long with the knowledge of what I did has made me understand otherwise.  I alone was accountable. V watches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is something wrong with us.  With all of mankind.  With me.  Something evil that made me enjoy what I did.  Some hideous flaw. Her voice almost trails off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We deserve to be culled.  We deserve it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light sweeps across Rosemary from the opening bedroom doo she sobs softly in bed.  Derek enters, holding a bottle o whiskey and his clean gun. She sits up as Derek looms over her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derek?  What? He lifts the gun into her bruised face.  Her eyebrows cri as he slowly pulls the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bang. Click.  It is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Rose.  I didn't load it. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not tonight. He grins evilly at her and answers the bedside phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almond.  What?!  Where? Derek's drunk eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god, yes!  God, thank you! He slams the phone down, charging out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gaggle of drunks exit the bar, laughing and singing as pass a small figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evey wanders into the bar amidst the lustful screams and calls for the line of high stepping, semi-clothed girls o stage. She stares out into the crowd, not sure why she is here w a man approaches her: Creedy.  His sloppy smile indicates has had a few drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look lost. She looks blankly at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I buy you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I made a mistake. She turns for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to find someone. Creedy frowns as his radio crackles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I didn't like the looks of you anyway --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All units, all units.  Code red.  Converge in Plaistow to apprehend codename V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody hell! He screams to the Fingermen at the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him!  We got him! Evey watches as they storm out of the bar, then follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The emergency lights blaring, Finch's car squeals around corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V hovers ghostly at Delia's bedside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's funny, I was given one of your roses today.  I wasn't sure you were the terrorist until I saw it. She manages a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a strange coincidence.  That I should be given it today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no coincidences, Delia.  Only the illusion of coincidence. He reaches into his cloak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have another rose.  This one is for you. He hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you are going to kill me now? V produces an empty syringe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I killed you ten minutes ago.  While you slept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any pain? V sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. She stares at the mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I -- Can I see your face again? V slowly pulls off his hat and lifts his mask.  Delia sta into his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful... The rose falls from her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V quietly shuts the door as if not to wake her and turns as -- Derek Almond reaches the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't move an inch, you bloody bastard. He trains his gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't hear me arrive, did you?  Didn't know we'd rumbled you? He squints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all finished, chummy.  All of it.  The old man told me it was my head or yours and what do you know.  It's yours. The smiling mask stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're standing over there with your bloody stupid knives and your fancy karate gimmicks -- Derek pulls back the hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I've got a gun. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bang. Click.  He never loaded it. There is an awkward moment of silence, then V moves -- Cloak opening, filling the hall like a black tidal wave t envelopes Derek.  He chokes a scream as V embraces him, slipping a knife above his floating rib. Derek Almond sputters as he claws at V's mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who -- Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, look.  Look and tell me what you see. He rips V's mask off as V thrusts the knife in deeper. Derek's eyes widen in horror as his life pours out the kn wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horrible!  God, it's horrible! V jerks his blade free, letting Derek slip to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finch's car bucks up onto the sidewalk. Finch and Dominic tear out of the car and barrel into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the top of the stairs, they find the dead Derek.  Finc rushes past him for the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delia? Inside, he finds her.  Her eyes fixed, cold, and dead, a single violet carson in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get an ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evey rushes around a corner to see a crime scene bathed i siren light.  She pushes up to the police barricade as th M.E.'s load a draped body into their van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no... V? She tries to angle around to get a better look when a man a brown overcoat grabs her from behind and drags her into alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the corner of the room, Finch sits, watching as the M.E.'s wheel out Delia's body. Dominic squeezes past the gurney and crosses toward Finch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir.  You knew the doctor pretty well? Finch nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found this on her bureau, sir.  It's Dr. Surridge's journal.  It covers her years at Larkhill.  It might contain the whole story. Dominic searches for something more to say when Finch doe not answer. After a moment, Finch looks at the book in Dominic's hand then takes it, leafing through the pages.  They flip by, breathy sigh, rising to a cold wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May 23rd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A younger Dr. Surridge, one by one, administers a series injections to her research stock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prothero has hand picked my subjects.  Four dozen of them, none of which will be any use to me if I don't get to work soon. She finishes an injection, Prothero encouraging the next subject.  We recognize her as the woman Prothero pointed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're so weak and pathetic I find myself hating them. Delia prepares the next dose, a sour look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't fight or struggle.  Just stare at you with weak eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
